newsitem.title: POLAND: POLISH CHURCH IN LAST STAND AGAINST ABORTION BILL.
newsitem.headline: POLISH CHURCH IN LAST STAND AGAINST ABORTION BILL.

text.p: Poland's Roman Catholic Church staged a massive last stand on Wednesday against a bill to liberalise Poland's tough anti-abortion law, as parliament held its final debate on an issue that has split the nation.

Tens of thousands of believers heard the Primate, Cardinal Jozef Glemp say a solemn mass against the measure at a central Warsaw church and then marched towards parliament waving such banners as: "We reject the legislation of death."

Lower house deputies will vote on Thursday whether to overthrow a Senate veto on the bill, which would let women end pregnancies before the 12th week if they faced financial or personal problems, but only after counselling and reflection.

Under the current law, passed in 1993 by a pro-Catholic government, abortions are now allowed only if a pregnancy threatens a woman's life or health, results from rape or incest, or when the foetus is irreparably damaged.
Poland's bishops, ending a plenary conference on Tuesday, wrote to deputies begging them not to pass the bill, which President Aleksander Kwasniewski has promised to sign into law.
"We understand that you face a decision which -- for various reasons -- is hard for you. But we appeal to you: Stand in defence of life," said the letter.
The Senate blocked the reform early this month and its lower house backers must secure a majority of 50 percent plus one vote to pass the measure, which they approved in August.
The vote could be close, but even some of the bill's opponents, who include members of the co-ruling Peasant party, admit that the reform is likely to pass.
The church fears a return to the situation before the 1989 fall of communism, when abortion was freely available.

The bill's backers, including the dominant ruling ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance (SLD), say the bill provides for sex education in schools and cheaper contraception and may even reduce the number of abortions.
These are anyway widely available in underground clinics or neighbouring countries to women with money.

"The current law has caused much social harm and human suffering. We cannot pretend that there is no problem, no abortion tourism or underground, that there are no abandoned infants," SLD deputy Izabella Sierakowska told parliament.
"Women cannot be made to give birth under compulsion. Love cannot be accompanied by fear," she declared.
The church, backed by the authority of Polish-born Pope John Paul, sees the bill as a licence to kill unborn children.
The issue is one of several deeply straining relations between the church and the ruling, secular-minded left, led by politicians who were part of the pre-1989 communist system.
On Monday the Episcopate's Secretary-General, Bishop Tadeusz Pieronek, said that these relations had never been so bad since 1993, when the ex-communists won parliamentary polls.

Apart from the abortion issue, the church and SLD have clashed over parliament's delays in ratifying a concordat treaty with the Vatican which was concluded by a previous, pro-Catholic government just before the 1993 elections.
The church also wants Poland's new constitution now being drafted to invoke God -- an idea rejected by much of the SLD.
Such issues may be a key theme in parliamentary polls next year, as 90 percent of Poles are at least nominally Catholics.

An alliance of right-wing parties grouped around the militantly pro-church Solidarity, which has promised to reverse the abortion bill is about level with the SLD in opinion polls. -- Warsaw Newsroom +48 22 653 9700
